model_answer: The monthly rent is to be paid on or before the 22nd day of each calendar month.
The landlord can charge an interest of 10% on an annual basis on the amount unpaid, calculated from after the date due up to the date of actual payment.

The security deposit is S$15,000, which is equivalent to 2 months' rental. It must be refunded within fourteen (14) days from the expiry or termination of the Tenancy Agreement, after any deductions for breaches of the agreement.
Yes, GIRO is an acceptable method for paying rent. The Tenant must provide evidence of the GIRO arrangement to the Landlord within 1 month from the commencement of the Tenancy Agreement.
The Tenant is responsible for paying all charges related to telephone, water, electricity, gas, and sewerage.

The defect-free period is 30 days, starting from the first day of the tenancy or the date the premises is handed over, whichever is later. The landlord is responsible for rectifying any defects identified by the tenant during this period.
The Tenant bears responsibility for all minor repairs and routine maintenance of the Premises, with a maximum amount of S$ 200 per job/repair/maintenance per item.

The items excluded from the tenant’s minor repairs obligation unless damage is due to the tenant’s negligence include the water heater, air conditioning system, built-in wardrobes, cabinets, toilet bowls, wash basins, ceiling, roof, wall structures, structural/main electrical wiring, and electrical box.
The Tenant is responsible for replacing light bulbs and tubes at their own expense.
The cost of replacing the item would be apportioned such that the Tenant bears the initial S200,whiletheLandlordcoverstheexcessamountofS200,whiletheLandlordcoverstheexcessamountofS150.
The Landlord pays for quarterly air-conditioning servicing and for repairs, unless the damage is caused by the act, neglect, or omission of the Tenant or their associates.
No, the tenant is not allowed to drill or alter the unit without obtaining prior written consent from the landlord.
Yes, the landlord can enter the premises for inspection or repairs at all reasonable times by prior appointment mutually agreed by both parties.

Yes. Authorised persons may view the premises during the final two months of the tenancy, provided there is a prior appointment mutually agreed. Viewings are permitted for re-letting or sale at reasonable times, and any sale remains subject to the existing tenancy unless otherwise agreed.
Subletting is not allowed without the prior written consent of the Landlord. However, the Landlord's consent shall not be unreasonably withheld for a respectable or reputable person or corporation.
The tenant must avoid doing or permitting anything on the premises that shall be or become a nuisance or annoyance or cause injury to the landlord or to the inhabitants of the neighboring premises.

The permitted use of the premises is as a private dwelling house only, and any breach of this use will result in immediate termination of the Tenancy Agreement. The tenant will forfeit their security deposit, which will be paid to or confiscated by the landlord, without affecting the landlord's right to take action for any breaches.
Pets are not permitted in the premises without the prior written permission of the Landlord. If permission is granted, any conditions imposed by the Landlord must be complied with.
The Tenant bears the fines for breaches of laws or by-laws during the tenancy.

Foreign occupiers must produce original employment passes, work permits, travel documents, identity cards, passports, and other relevant documents evidencing their legal entry and stay in Singapore. The Tenant is responsible for the verification of these documents from original documentation.
No, the tenant is not required to repaint the unit at the end of the lease if it is due to fair wear and tear.
The tenant is allowed reasonable hanging of pictures, but before the lease expires all nails, screws and hooks should be taken out and any remaining holes properly patched with white putty.
No, the tenant will not be liable to pay any Gross Rent during the rectification period, which includes the time until the completion of rectification works.

The tenant has the right to peaceably hold and enjoy the premises during the tenancy without any interruption by the landlord or any person rightfully claiming under or in trust for the landlord, provided the tenant pays the reserved rents and adheres to the tenancy agreement's terms and conditions.

The landlord must execute repairs, replacement, and renewal of the fixtures and fittings, including electrical appliances, due to fair wear and tear within fourteen (14) days upon receipt of notice from the tenant.
The landlord insures against fire damage to the landlord’s property.

The named tenant can end the lease early using the diplomatic clause after 12 months if they are deported, refused permission to work or reside in Singapore, or transferred to another country. They must provide at least 2 months' notice or pay 2 months' rent in lieu of notice, along with documentary evidence by the termination date.
Yes, if the diplomatic clause is lawfully exercised, the Tenant must reimburse the Landlord commission paid to the agency on a pro-rata basis for the remaining unfulfilled term of the tenancy.

The renewal option allows the Tenant to request a renewal of the tenancy for an additional year, provided the request is made in writing at least 2 months before the current tenancy expires and there are no breaches of the contract. The clauses that do not apply during the renewal term are the 'Option to Renew' clause and the 'diplomatic clause.'
Notices are served by sending a registered letter to the Tenant or Landlord at their specified address or via email. The stamp duty for this tenancy is to be borne by the tenant and paid forthwith.
